importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the article was published and when the federal government shutdown was ongoing, directly affecting the timeline of SNAP program funding and state actions.
The start date of the federal government shutdown that triggered the funding crisis in the food stamp program.

importantTimeframes.approximateTimeFrameEnd: Two weeks from the article's publication date
importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The USDA projected that the food stamp program would run out of funds in two weeks, leading to potential loss of benefits for millions of Americans in November.

keyTakeAways: Roughly 42 million Americans are at risk of losing food stamp benefits in November due to the federal government shutdown.
The USDA has not enough funds to pay full SNAP benefits in November, with a projected shortfall of around $8 billion in required benefits versus available contingency funding of $6 billion.
The Trump administration blamed Democrats for the shutdown, accusing them of prioritizing political agendas over food security.
New York Governor Kathy Hochul criticized the administration for halting benefits, calling it a deliberate move to harm vulnerable families.
The food stamp program is the second major nutrition assistance program at risk, following WIC, which received a $300 million tariff revenue infusion to avoid depletion.
17 states have stopped accepting new food stamp applications because their systems require partial payments that can't be processed under current funding constraints.
The program is especially critical as Thanksgiving approaches, with food pantries already overstretched and unable to compensate.
The USDA has a contingency fund of $6 billion, but it is insufficient to cover the projected $8 billion in November benefits.
Previous shutdowns have shown that temporary workarounds (like obligated payments within 30 days) have been used, but this time, those are not available or sufficient.
Advocacy groups stress that the administration must act urgently to protect vulnerable families from food insecurity.

namedEntities.name: Tami Luhby
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the author of the news article reporting on the food stamp program crisis, providing credibility and context to the coverage.

namedEntities.name: Brooke Rollins
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Agriculture Secretary under the Trump administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She announced that the food stamp program would run out of money in two weeks and blamed Democrats for the shutdown, making her a central figure in the political narrative.

namedEntities.name: Kathy Hochul
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She publicly criticized the Trump administration for halting food stamp benefits, highlighting the humanitarian impact on vulnerable families.

namedEntities.name: Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is a critical safety net for low-income Americans, and its potential shutdown threatens food security for millions.

namedEntities.name: WIC
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Women, Infants, and Children food assistance program
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is another key nutrition program at risk, though temporarily protected by a $300 million tariff revenue infusion.

namedEntities.name: United States Department of Agriculture (USDA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal agency overseeing food assistance programs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is directly responsible for managing the SNAP program and has announced funding shortfalls and state-level payment pauses.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. federal government leadership during the shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is central to the political debate, with officials both blaming Democrats and attempting to maintain funding for key programs.

namedEntities.name: Democrats
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Political party in opposition to the Trump administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are accused of prioritizing political agendas over food security, and they argue that Republicans refused to negotiate a spending deal.

namedEntities.name: Republicans
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Political party that holds the current administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are held responsible for the impasse over spending, and their stance on negotiation is central to the funding debate.

namedEntities.name: Obamacare premium subsidies
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Healthcare subsidies under the Affordable Care Act
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Democrats argue that Republicans refused to extend these subsidies, contributing to the political stalemate causing the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Tariff revenue
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Funds generated from tariffs used to support nutrition programs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A $300 million shift from tariff revenue kept WIC afloat, but not enough to support SNAP in November.

namedEntities.name: Gina Plata-Nino
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Acting director of SNAP at the Food Research & Action Center
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She underscores the critical importance of SNAP in feeding vulnerable families, especially around Thanksgiving.

namedEntities.name: Ty Jones Cox
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Vice president of food assistance at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She advocates for urgent action to protect families from losing food stamps during the shutdown.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Millions of Americans are at risk of losing access to food stamps in November due to the federal government shutdown, with the USDA warning that the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) will run out of funds in two weeks. The Trump administration blamed Democrats for the shutdown, claiming they prioritized political agendas over food security, while Democrats argue that Republicans refused to negotiate a spending deal including extended Obamacare subsidies. Although WIC was temporarily protected by a $300 million tariff revenue infusion, SNAP lacks sufficient funding, with its $6 billion contingency fund falling short of the $8 billion needed for November benefits. As a result, 17 states have suspended new food stamp applications. Advocacy groups emphasize that the program is especially vital around Thanksgiving and that urgent action is needed to prevent widespread food insecurity among vulnerable families.
title: Millions of Americans at Risk of Losing Food Stamps Next Month Amid Shutdown
